issue.title: liboqs.so: found executable STACK entry: GNU_STACK RWE
issue.body:
I decided to enable strict ELF checker in ALT Linux when building liboqs package, and it reported that `liboqs.so` have executable stack:

`verify-elf: ERROR: ./usr/lib64/liboqs.so.0.7.1: found executable STACK entry:   GNU_STACK      0x000000 0x0000000000000000 0x0000000000000000 0x000000 0x000000 RWE 0x10`

This is output of `readelf --wide --segments -- ./usr/lib64/liboqs.so.0.7.1` and executable stack is marked with letter `E' in flags column.

Executable stack is rare occurrence these days so you might want to fix it somehow.

comment.body:
After some investigation it seems related to compiling asm (.S) files which does not contain proper [markings](https://www.win.tue.nl/~aeb/linux/hh/protection.html).

It helped locally to build with `-DCMAKE_ASM_FLAGS=` with added `-Wa,--noexecstack`.

issue.title: liboqs.so: found executable STACK entry: GNU_STACK RWE
issue.body:
I decided to enable strict ELF checker in ALT Linux when building liboqs package, and it reported that `liboqs.so` have executable stack:

`verify-elf: ERROR: ./usr/lib64/liboqs.so.0.7.1: found executable STACK entry:   GNU_STACK      0x000000 0x0000000000000000 0x0000000000000000 0x000000 0x000000 RWE 0x10`

This is output of `readelf --wide --segments -- ./usr/lib64/liboqs.so.0.7.1` and executable stack is marked with letter `E' in flags column.

Executable stack is rare occurrence these days so you might want to fix it somehow.

comment.body: Thanks for the issue.  I've tried to add this option via #1161.  Can you check if that resolves the issue?  I don't have the full toolchain installed to easily check.

issue.title: Add support for powerpc64
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
﻿This is 64-bit POWER big-endian. Since s390x (64-bit big-endian) and ppc64le
(64-bit POWER) are already supported, this shouldn't be an issue.
This PR adds support for 64-bit POWER on big-endian.
There is already support for one 64-bit big-endian architecture (s390x).
There is also support for ppc64le (64-bit POWER little-endian).
So this PR shouldn't add much overhead.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: Thanks for the PR. Do you know of any resources for running continuous integration on this platform?

issue.title: Mark stack non-executable when compiling with clang or gcc
issue.body:
Fixes #1159

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [No] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [No] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
Thanks. We using gcc to build liboqs (and solution with `-Wa,...` is tested to work). In that case you just adding `-Wl,-z,noexecstack`. I tested this commit and it still produces executable stack. (Maybe some linking is still missing this flag?) Why not to always add `-Wa,--noexecstack` to `CMAKE_ASM_FLAGS` for both compilers?

```
$ grep '\.S' log2 | grep -v noexec -c
4
$ grep '\.S' log2 | grep -v noexec
[2350/2366] : && /usr/bin/cc -pipe -frecord-gcc-switches -Wall -fdiagnostics-color=always -fdiagnostics-color=always -fdiagnostics-color=always -g -O2 -flto=auto -O2 -g -DNDEBUG  src/common/sha3/xkcp_low/CMakeFiles/xkcp_low_keccakp_1600_plain64.dir/KeccakP-1600/plain-64bits/KeccakP-1600-opt64.c.o src/common/sha3/xkcp_low/CMakeFiles/xkcp_low_keccakp_1600times4_serial.dir/KeccakP-1600times4/serial/KeccakP-1600-times4-on1.c.o src/common/sha3/xkcp_low/CMakeFiles/xkcp_low_keccakp_1600_avx2.dir/KeccakP-1600/avx2/KeccakP-1600-AVX2.S.o src/common/sha3/xkcp_low/CMakeFiles/xkcp_low_keccakp_1600times4_avx2.dir/KeccakP-1600times4/avx2/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/aes/aes_ossl.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/sha2/sha2_ossl.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/sha3/xkcp_sha3.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/sha3/xkcp_sha3x4.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/common.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/pqclean_shims/nistseedexpander.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/pqclean_shims/fips202.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/pqclean_shims/fips202x4.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/rand/rand.c.o src/common/CMakeFiles/common.dir/rand/rand_nist.c.o tests/CMakeFiles/test_hash.dir/test_hash.c.o -o tests/test_hash  /usr/lib64/libcrypto.so  -lm && :
...
```
So something is linked without `noexecstack`.

issue.title: Add support for powerpc64
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
﻿This is 64-bit POWER big-endian. Since s390x (64-bit big-endian) and ppc64le
(64-bit POWER) are already supported, this shouldn't be an issue.
This PR adds support for 64-bit POWER on big-endian.
There is already support for one 64-bit big-endian architecture (s390x).
There is also support for ppc64le (64-bit POWER little-endian).
So this PR shouldn't add much overhead.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
I don't think there are any that provide out-of-the-box. But e.g. OpenSSL crosscompiles for plenty of platforms: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/.github/workflows/cross-compiles.yml

That said, I think it may be ok if liboqs builds on both ppc64le and s390x.

comment.body: Build is failing on our Ubuntu bionic i386 image.  Seems to be related to an old version of CMake that doesn't support add\_link\_options.  Can we upgrade CMake in that image?  (The option was added in CMake 3.13, apparently; which came out in November 2018.)
